titleInfo.title: Influence of Influencers on Appearance Comparison and Eating Disorder Risk in College Women

mods:mods.abstract: Social media has been linked to increased eating disorder (ED) risk by exposing users to thin-idealized content posted by celebrities and peers and triggering appearance comparison. Social media influencers post idealized content on social media to advertise for external companies under the guise of being relatable, therefore representing a new source of influence for social media users. Influencers combine the relatability of peers with the thin appearance of celebrities, thus embodying potentially harmful qualities of both groups. Therefore, it is crucial to understand the potential deleterious effects of viewing influencer content on appearance comparison and eating pathology in high-risk groups such as college women. The current study utilized an experimental design where college women (n = 354) were randomly assigned to view images depicting 1) peers (n=89); 2) influencers (n=88); 3) celebrities (n=90); or 4) travel (control condition; n=87). Participants completed pre and post self-report measures of ED risk factors, measures of state and trait appearance comparison, and a behavioral measure assessing dietary restraint. For the behavioral measure, participants ordered a hypothetical dinner from Panera restaurant, and caloric and macronutrient contents of participants' intended food consumption were calculated as a continuous measure of dietary restraint. We examined between-group differences in momentary changes in ED risk factors and caloric and macronutrient contents of participants' intended Panera consumption. State appearance comparison was examined as a potential mediator for the effect of condition on ED risk, and trait appearance comparison was examined as a potential moderator for the effect of condition on momentary ED risk ratings. Participants' momentary anxiety decreased whereas their ED cognitions and urge to exercise increased following all conditions. Viewing images of celebrities caused greater increases in participants' momentary ED risk factors compared to viewing control images. No significant differences emerged for viewing influencers' or peers' images. State appearance comparison partially mediated the effect of celebrity vs. control condition on specific ED risk factors. Viewing FSU peer images had a greater effect on post-intervention specific ED risk factors for those high in trait appearance comparison. Participants' Panera order did not differ across experimental groups. These results reveal the complexity of how social comparison impacts the effect of social media images on ED risk factors and suggest that influencer images may be no more detrimental than other types of images one might encounter on social media.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor in Philosophy.
body image, eating disorders, influencers, Instagram, mental health, social media
Pamela K. Keel, Professor Directing Dissertation; Dawn Carr, University Representative; Norman B. Schmidt, Committee Member; Jesse Cougle, Committee Member; Jon Maner, Committee Member.
